title: Case Study 16: Ollie Otoscope
chief_complaint: I am here for audiologic testing due to a history of progressive hearing problems.

problem_summary.onset: Congenital/Early childhood. Newborn screening passed Right, referred Left. Progression noted at age 3 (Left) and age 4 (Right).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Enlarged vestibular aqueducts (EVA) identified on imaging at age 4.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Requires amplification; currently uses a BTE hearing aid in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitor hearing thresholds and manage progression.

history.present_illness: Ollie is 6 years old with a history of progressive hearing loss. He passed newborn screening on the right but referred on the left. ABR at 2 months showed moderate SNHL in the left ear and normal hearing in the right. He was fit with a left BTE hearing aid.
history.otologic_history: Progression of loss in left ear noted at age 3. Hearing loss emerged in right ear at age 4. Imaging (CT/MRI) at age 4 revealed enlarged vestibular aqueducts bilaterally.
history.prior_management: Left BTE hearing aid since infancy.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present when stimulating the Right ear (Ipsi R, Contra L) but absent when stimulating the Left ear (Ipsi L, Contra R), consistent with severe left-sided afferent deficit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Mild low/mid-frequency SNHL sloping to moderately-severe/severe in high frequencies. Left ear: Moderate-to-severe sloping to profound SNHL. Bone conduction consistent with sensorineural loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows excellent discrimination. Left ear shows very poor discrimination even at high intensity.

tests.name: Wideband Reflectance
tests.key_findings: Reflectance patterns appear similar between ears, generally consistent with normal middle ear status shown in tympanometry.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, consistent with the diagnosis of Enlarged Vestibular Aqueducts (EVA). The Right ear exhibits a mild sloping to severe hearing loss with excellent speech recognition. The Left ear exhibits a moderate sloping to profound hearing loss with very poor speech recognition (16%). Middle ear function is normal bilaterally.
counseling_points: Discuss the progressive nature of hearing loss associated with Enlarged Vestibular Aqueducts (EVA).
Emphasize the importance of avoiding head trauma and contact sports to preserve residual hearing.
Recommend fitting/adjustment of amplification for the Right ear given the progression.
Discuss the limited benefit of the current hearing aid in the Left ear due to poor speech clarity (16% WRS).
Refer for Cochlear Implant evaluation for the Left ear.
Recommend FM/DM system use in the classroom to support learning.
notes_for_actor: Portray a concerned parent if the patient is a child, or the child himself if age-appropriate.
Focus on the anxiety regarding the recent drop in hearing in the 'good' (right) ear.
Ask questions about whether the hearing will get worse and if sports are safe.
